I can't speak for other jurisdictions, but in the UK the distinction is increasingly blurred. For example, one can pretty much sack an employee of less than two years without giving a reason (provided one hasn't discriminated against them on the basis of a "protected characteristic", e.g. race/sex/sexuality/disability/religion/etc). Furthermore, there is an increasing trend towards "zero-hours contracts" whereby people are technically employed but there is no commitment to provide any minimum amount of work (or provide any minimum amount of compensation).

Thanks for this answer. I do agree that one should tell everybody of the idea for the startup. However, I am not talking about the idea (which I communicate to everybody) but about the greater vision, which is enabled by the idea. For example: Idea: Internet-/crowd-based encyclopedia. Vision: Gather all of humanities knowledge in one place and make it freely accessible.

I don't see a large gap between the idea and the vision of a startup. I think communicating your vision can help to strengthen and emphasize your idea when communicating it. Sharing your vision which is presumably also your main motivation helps folks to understand your product/idea etc.

I'd sooner invest in someone with grand, ambitious plans than someone whose vision is small and narrow--*provided that* they are prepared to put in the graft required to get there. That's the difference between a dreamer and an entrepreneur.

It's not always good. It's an election to be taxed today on stuff you don't yet legally own. That's only good if the tax would be very low today, or if you expect significant increase in value between now and when you sell it. Property you get as compensation is ordinary income; stock you own as an investment is capital gain, with a much lower tax rate. The election lets you claim today's low value as your compensation. If the stock doesn't have a low value today, then the election can be very difficult.

@Avestron: Clearly I disagree, and in my opinion, your opinions sound like enterprise business speak; startups are not enterprises, and enterprises are not startups - and to think they are is dangerous in my opinion.

My opinions on the matter of idea disclosure are based on fundamental fear. An idea is a very fickle possession. Once you show a colleague a physical possession (such as a brand new watch) you remain the owner of the possession in question. An idea is easily claimed and stolen. That idea can then be developed and thrive in its being shared and being profited upon while its originator's fate is less than irrelevant. Admittedly a pessimistic viewpoint but the world we live in isn't exactly one of rainbows and sunshine either.
That is an interesting perspective. In your experience, when you have been approached by persons with ideas, what qualities would you have desired them to have (besides finances)?

@Avestron My weak point is sales, so anyone who address that gets more ... points :) Other than that, I care a lot about how "compatible" the other person(s) is with me. If we can't communicate or have a totally different set of values, we are not going to succeed. I also care a lot about what drives the person. I strongly prefer people very ambitious people over idealists, because unless the project is THE great way to promote his ideals, he is likely to lose interest at some point down the road over the next great thing. Finally, a well-connected person in the target niche, is usually a go.

I see - my conclusion then (which should have been suspected earlier) is that each technical person will themselves have 'weak points' that are desirable to be complimented by corresponding 'strong points' in the prospective ideas person. :) Likewise it makes sense to desire a person well-connected within the field in question if one is not already.

Lastly it would make sense for a person entering into a business relationship to seek assusances that a prospective partner has the energy and focus to follow through with a project. Idealists are more in danger of perfectionism getting in the way of progress rather than lacking ambition. Also - I imagine that to a technical person it is preferable that an ideas person has few ideas that s/he has a deep understanding of rather than many ideas that s/he has a shallow or shaky understanding of. (i.e. wouldn't it be cool if...). :)

We developed an IR application, applied to patents search, and the results the application provided were really encouraging compared to prior art (according to me). Before trying to market it as a search service I was considering how to create freedom-to-operate condition, and the choices were mainly two: publishing on company web site or submitting to field journal (Springer, etc.). So the algorithm (not the software implementation) would be disclosed and published, but this is somehow necessary in order to justify the supposed advancement in results.

This is somehow similar to open software business model, but with some differences: it is the algorithm to be “given away” and not the software implementation, that would have proprietary copyright. So the business model would be something like: we offer an IR service. The technology is supposed to have something interesting but to lever on this advantage to market it as a service it's necessary to disclose it. So we have a first business assumption (a): even if competitors then would be free to implement their software version, anyway the first company to develop it (us) would be ahead.

Be careful when approaching investors with the claim that you do not have any competitors. They will probably assume that you are not properly prepared. Your product will either solve some kind of problem for your customers (e.g. simplifying tax returns) or satisfy a basic need (e.g. food, electricity, entertainment). I get most of your point, but there are a couple things I either don't understand or disagree with. You say it is "not unlimited not off". If you're not limiting it, I would expect that to qualify as "unlimited", and if they're not required to do work during that time I would consider that "off" so I'm not sure where you're coming from there. I realize some employees would (especially initially) feel weird about the extra freedom, but if you handled it correctly in making clear you were okay with them taking more than X days off I don't think it would be "gaming the way humans behave".

Not sure why it has to be complex. And while I can see an argument for getting paid for unused days being a better option (though I feel that would be matter of preference), I would at least think this would be better than what that majority of employers I (and most people I know) have worked for do which is simply drop any unused days (above a certain number which roll over) without paying you for them at all. I don't understand the argument that most people wouldn't use it if they're not going to lose it.

Finally - I agree with your initial statement of trust except that when someone breeches that trust the outcome is not always beneficial to all (in this situation or any other). @JRWarren: "I don't understand the argument that most people wouldn't use it if they're not going to lose it." - In my experience, the majority of time off is used in two ways, people that take time off yearly, and those that don't, but have the benefit, accrue time to the max, and only spend it when their are going to lose it. All in all I suggest you spend more time on researching what crowd funding is about and what THEY want to see from you. That will help you align your goals with theirs.

MVP = MINIMUM Viable Product. Which means encryption is only necessary for an MVP if that's the whole purpose of the product (e.g. a product for the security industry). Which in your case it's not.

Security is a system-wide issue and encompasses many aspects. e.g. A hacker could more easily access users messages if you're storing them somewhere on the server-side, which makes any encryption of little use. Intercepting IP packets and reconstituting the message is often more effort than breaking into a server, or exploiting known weaknesses. So any effort to make a 'secure' system should start with the design and architecture.
Your assumption seems to be that encrypting the traffic would make your service somehow 'secure' and impenetrable from hackers. It won't. See above.

I think my approach is more like "minimum viable product" (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Minimum_viable_product). That is to build a core feature only of my product and immediately test it in real world. By doing that, I can have a very useful feedback from customers and from there I can make the adjustment effectively. That is like "Build Fast, Fail Fast, Learn Fast"

Actualy, my solution is like "Lean startup" (http://theleanstartup.com/principles). That is you have an idea, then build the core first, then test it, then adjust gradually... @dan14941 It depends. Copyrights are a bit complicated, because they actually exist immediately and implicitly when you create something. In other words, your app and code are already copyrighted. Registering that copyright "just" gives you the ability to enforce it. Because of that, posting "Copyright (c) <year> <company" isn't necessary, but it can help give notice, which is good for litigation. I wouldn't bother in source, personally, but yes, the top would be a good place. And I'd probably put it on my app's about page. But those mean different things.

You can check out [this related answer](http://startups.stackexchange.com/a/826/59) about what it means to copyright code. But essentially, copyrighting code has very little to do with your app. It's good, because then people can't steal your literal source code, but chances are that nobody will see your source code anyway.

I actually disagree. Good developers should use distributed source control _when it makes sense for the project at hand_. If you're on a project where you care more about knowing what any given developer was working on at any given time, a centralized SCM may actually make more sense -- git lets you do operations that throw away historical data about work-in-progress revisions. That data can be valuable -- if you want to know someone's thought process or a bug's exact origin, seeing the interim steps they went through in building a piece of code before rebase/merge can be valuable.

Anyhow -- it's a longer discussion. I've worn the source control / build management hat at several startups, using several different version control systems, and I don't think it's as clear-cut as "anyone who would ever use a centralized SCM is obviously a bad developer".

Might be wrong, but appears you're saying traction and it's growth define product-market-fit. If so, then in my opinion, it's possible that might be a sign, though also very possible it might not; aka [hockey stick growth](http://1.bp.blogspot.com/-GmupD9a8fA8/UzGnNiniigI/AAAAAAAACWk/yC8VMr6sF3s/s1600/Hockey+stick+graph.jpg). Am I missing something?

You're not missing anything. Product-market fit is all about interest and traction (with potential profitability to boot). You either have some or you don't. If you do, you survive and grow -- potentially very fast. If you don't, your product is no good or it's a solution that's running around looking for a problem.

Seems a bit circular to me, since my understanding is that Product/Market Fit is the degree to which a product satisfies the overall demand of a market; meaning you need to be able to measure both the demand for the market AND the product, not just the demand for the product.
Would a startup usually seek professional advice on the content of the ToS and the correct type of insurance? If so where would one find such a service?

No, no, no... your logic is somewhat mixed up. You do NOT somehow evolve a product so it fits a market. You start by finding out what the market needs, you then run the idea with prospects, you ultimately sign clients, and *then* you build the product. Nearly all entrepreneurs I interact with make that mistake, btw: they build first, worry about selling later, and evolve the product as they move along. They end up with little or no traction. The ones that aren't in this situation are fixing a very specific problem they have themselves, or are very lucky.

Any legal document (including ToS) needs professional advice, I'd say. As for insurance, you'll probably be stuck with whatever your favourite insurance company offers, as a customized policy is most likely too expensive for a startup.

Believe I understand your response, though unclear how you reached that based on my prior comment. All I'm saying is that the demand for a solution is not the same as a demand for a market. My understanding of your answer is that you're defining Product/Market Fit by the demand for the product, not the demand for the product relative to the demand of the market. (Any rate, happy to let you have the last comment, or move this to chat, since there's no value you in my opinion in having long comment threads below an answer.)

If you live in Ontario, like the Canadian province, then you don't have a green card. You have a plastic card that has no meaning because it is no longer valid to show for your status. By living in Canada you forfeited your status as a US permanent resident.
@littleadv - a green card doesn't become invalid the moment you leave the country.
@DenisdeBernardy no, it becomes invalid when you take residence elsewhere.

@littleadv - If you re-enter the US often enough while continuing to pay IRS taxes from a US address, your green card can remain valid for a while. It becomes invalid if you leave the US and tell the IRS you're no longer a resident, or if you stay out of the country for too long (over a year if memory serves). Even then, though, there's a special Visa (SB-1) for green card holders who left for reasons beyond their control with the intent of coming back -- e.g. a relative needed nursing or your boss sent you to another country.

@DenisdeBernardy no. What you're describing is concealing the truth. If you behave as if you never left the US, and try to avoid telling the agencies that you did - you may hope that they won't find out. But legally - you lost your green card. Its just that you're hoping they won't notice. Like when you "forget" to write down income on your tax return and hope they won't notice. They may not, and you won't pay taxes - but its not that didn't owe them, right? Same thing.

@littleadv - No, really... There are plenty of perfectly valid cases for maintaining an address abroad while lawfully keeping a green card. For instance, when a business exec or an engineer is out of the country on a regular basis and for extended periods of time for business reasons (e.g. they're regularly called in to bootstrap or manage stuff in other countries). Or when a student goes to a foreign university while their parents stay in the US. Or when you fly home for extended periods of time to nurse a dying relative. Only the thickest public servants would see any problems with these.

@DenisdeBernardy its not up to the thickest public servants. Not at all. You can request a REP if you're going for more than half a year. You can even extend it for two years, if you have a really valid reason. But you're still **temporary** abroad. A person who comes and says that he's **living** in Ontario, and considering starting a business **in Canada** is by no means a US permanent resident.

If I understand you correctly you are implementing something like a social Q&A platform, so you're trying to get into an existing market. In a situation like that it probably makes more sense to find a niche in that market and create a perfect solution for that niche. It could start exclusively for your country or the region you live in. Don't try to conquer the whole market at once. So maybe you want to step back a bit. Read a bit about lean startup. Do some customer development. Try to do that in person. Maybe on a college campus, where students have questions and want to be social.

Other than that, I would focus on a web service solution first. It should be fairly easy to create "web service client apps" for both Android and iOS - they will be just something like a thin presentation and interaction layer for your web service. For implementing the apps you may also want to consider cross platform development frameworks such as PhoneGap, so you can launch your app on both platforms simultaneously.

I some how missed that note on research costs, so thank you. However, in response to your comment "As to your background, it does not really matter," in the United States this isn't true. The IRS, who manages most taxation, will commonly reclassify a business as a hobby if you show no profits, especially if they deem your experience as not related. It's more complex than that, but basically if a painter spent five years and $100k researching a new kind of cement, they could get into trouble in year 3, with the IRS saying the money can't be written off because there is no profit, and that

(continued) the painter wouldn't be expected to have the experience to know how to create a new kind of cement, and therefor it's probably a cover for a hobby. Once the IRS says they think one thing, you're guilty until proven innocent. All it takes is for them to decide it isn't a business, then send you a bill for all of the past years taxes without those business deductions, plus penalty and interest. If you disagree, you have to go to court.

In the case of my painter analogy, the idea would be to not write off any of those expenses until the new concrete is done. Then it's much easier to prove that there were legitimate business expenses.

My experience is that @Mowzer is spot on here. Startup equity is very high risk. Good developers are highly paid skilled professionals. If you put yourself in their shoes — why would you choose an equity-only compensation? Only if you're highly invested in the organisation. Which means something close to co-founderish status. Otherwise you're looking for £ + equity as bonus/golden-handcuffs.
If they *are* people you know — it will *still* be a really hard sell ;-)
To further add, Musk had a really hard time managing both SpaceX and Tesla at the same time. He almost lost everything.

@Mowzer a great example of this is crowdfunding, and a more commonly used term for "pre-selling" is preordering. Sites like Kickstarter allow you to find consumers who want your product, and "pre-sell" your product idea to them with the hope that someday they'll actually get it. This of course comes with the trade-offs of every competitor out there knowing your idea, sometimes before it's even started development, and lost time in marketing. Those trade-offs are often why people cofound companies, or offer equity in return for work; to keep the idea secret, and focus on just development.

@Mowzer is right. People, especially early on, want to feel compensated with not just equity, but title as well. It would be a shame to be the first employee at a company that has no product, build the product for them, and then not be considered a cofounder.
Just remember, no matter what you do, your most valuable currency is time, because the time you put in you can never get back. Be cautious!

A finished product that you can sell is the result of a series of steps. Howard Taylor states that the idea has no value "until I actually write the scripts", but he then goes on to admit that the scripts have "limited" value themselves. But the word "limited" implies *some* value. Drawing on them adds a little more value, and Travis colouring them a little more, etc. He then erroneously concludes that they "become a product ... and **then** they have value". But he's missed the point that every single step along the way added value, and the final product's value is the sum of its parts.

@JBentley I have found the phrase "the final product's value is the sum of its parts" to lead me astray. I find products are better thought of as gestalts: the final product is *different* from the sum of its parts. After the fact, you can try to divide the product up into its parts and try to assign value, but that process is always harder than it seems. The idea is the hardest bit. Tim Berners-Lee had the idea for the internet. Did that entitle him to 50% of the value of the internet after someone else made it happen? No...

... In fact, while people give him credit for "inventing the internet," what really got him the fame is that he took that idea and ran with it, encouraging it and inspiring it, until it became something people wanted. Then it had value. I have an idea for a privacy enabled Facebook. Why don't I go make 50% on it? Because that idea is way simpler than the task of coding it up and marketing it. In fact, I fully believe my particular idea has been had by thousands of people already who haven't had the resources to bring it to fruition.
From C2.com: [Ideas Are Worthless](http://c2.com/cgi/wiki?IdeasAreWorthless)

That doesn't contradict what I'm saying. Yes, it is difficult calculate *what* the value of a particular part of the process should be, but that doesn't mean it has *no* value. Every step in the process, without which you could not make the final product, has a value. In the example you gave, the value of the idea is low because it is an obvious idea. In the case of the idea behind a work of literature, the idea is highly valued because few people would have conceived of the same idea. A book is worth more than the effort of merely putting words on paper.

@adrianh - Agreed fully with respect to hiring a lawyer. But Germany follows Roman Law rather than Common Law. Verbal contracts don't have as much value on this side of the Channel at on yours. For the most part they only hold if there's a repeated precedent, e.g. if you're used to getting a yearly bonus at Christmas and getting the latter suddenly stops then you've a case.

I stand corrected! Apologies. I knew somebody who had some verbal contracts around work/shares between a German company and himself (he was Swiss) about ten years back. As I recall the verbal agreements were taking into account — but my memory is fallible :-)

@adrianh - Actually, you're technically right. Verbal or habit-based agreements do count. But it's in very specific cases in practice. Common Law judges have a lot of leeway compared to Roman Law judges, so it's easy to assume something valid here is valid there and vice versa. What happened to your friend likely revolved around him having nothing inked and signed, but still having a large amount of documentation to that effect. That counts.

I have to partially disagree on this answer. If two companies make a contract together then usually the last provided T&C are applicable. This means if you send an offer with your T&C and a company places an order with you with their T&C and you accept the order, then the other T&C prevail. To make your own T&C a priority you need to send an order acknowledgement where you are clearly highlighting that your T&C are applicable and attach your T&C to the acknowledgement. Note that even the example shown says "In the event of a conflict [...] order acknowledgment" and not compared to the offer.

I would like to add additionally that when sending an order acknowledgement which is not 100% in line with the Purchase Order then no final contract has been established yet. Your client might decline the contract with your T&C.

Yes, I would suggest to pick one client and work with them first. Pilot - means first or experimental. This means, that once you find your first client, you do the following: create logins for them, help them to import their initial data (if needed), setup your software for them, teach them in person how to use your software, collect their feedback every few days, fix al the issues they find, do some additional features if they need them (not all of them). You baby-sit them. Then you will understand what your customer wants, what are the problems with your software, how your customer uses it.

Of course you can sign an agreement. And the most common penalty is: if you do not deliver, you do not get paid. But first maybe you should select those freelancers carefully. Do not expose your startup to the risk of failing because some freelancer is not serious or professional in his/her behavior.

No, because Income tax is a tax on a person, not a company.
Shares are not products. Shares are investment. When you put money in to a bank savings account, it is an investment. Do you think the bank pays tax on this? They don't.

You need to separate the two entities. Company/Corporate Taxes, and Employee/Personal Taxes. If a share holder sells their shares, and profits from the sale, there will likely be a tax on the profits (called Capital Gains Tax). I say likely because it varies in each country - if the profit are small, or if the investment was in an industry that helps with job growth, it might win special tax treatment, but normally, when you profit, the taxman wants a share of your success. On the otherhand, if you make a loss, you typically can write that against other tax owed and lower your tax liability.

If a corporation sells shares, the only tax that I can think that might apply is the tax on the administrative service behind the selling, or buying of the shares. If you think of it, the paperwork behind the buying/selling of the shares is unlikely to be done by employees working for free.

@jpaugh - I'm a JS programmer myself...but I can admit that the main popularity of dynamically typed languages stems from the fact that they're easier to use with a lesser understanding of what you're actually doing, opening them up to far lesser skilled people. With a skilled programmer at the helm the deeper understanding of working with the the strong types is not an impediment and the easier bug handling and better optimizations possible in the engine become very useful.

@JimboJonny My point was that Java is *weakly* typed, even though it is statically typed. It's really hard to write code in Java that is both general and type-safe. (Try serializing a `List`, for example.) The type system is not strong enough to pick up enough useful properties of data types in order to generalize over them without resorting to casting, and dynamic type checking (via reflection). So, basically, one is forced to do dynamic typing in Java, anyway to overcome the limitations of its weak static type system.
Languages like Python simply embrace that shortcoming, and make it much less verbose to do the dynamic bits.

@NicolasRaoul In reality, your competition is probably using the word 'brand' because it sounds a little warmer than the word 'company' in the advertising copy. @TomDworzanski I think it's helpful to separate the two because one will keep the other afloat during times of crisis. In Volkswagen's case, the brand is strong enough that people will stick with them through the scandal. Then the opposite is true of Uber. Uber are really strong as a company because they've invented a new (and largely untested) business model. So people are willing to stick through the aches and pains of negative experiences while the business finds its footing.

I'll add that the need for branding also depends on the industry you're in. If your company is Boeing— then your customers care mostly about the 'company' side of the equation. I.e. buying an airplane that works. So branding isn't as important. But if you're a company Jeep or BMW, then you're operating in a crowded space, and people are buying your product (at least partly) because of the statement it makes about them. I don't think it's quite so simple. At very least, so far as the UK is concerned (and I would assume the same in Singapore), the NV LLC would probably be considered to have established an office within its jurisdiction requiring separate registration here. That may be straightforward enough, but it's yet more admin to pile on top of simply working as a sole trader without as much bureaucratic headache.

Also, different tax jurisdictions will assess taxes in different ways. An NV LLC with an office in the UK is still subject to UK Corporation Tax on its UK activities, and is also subject to UK sales tax (VAT) if UK sales are over the threshold. Singapore, I've no idea. So really, structures like this require professional advice from people who understand all the various issues from each relevant jurisdiction. As regards the salary/dividends she'd receive from the NV LLC whilst living here: those would be subject to both UK income tax (as a UK resident) and US income tax (as a US citizen).

I would suggest, for your sanity and simplicity, that you forget fancy structures and she just work as a sole trader in each country as required. You've not explained whether this has been considered—or, if so, why it has been dismissed in favour of complex international company structures?

If her UK visa does not permit her to work, then no structure is going to overcome that: the purpose of non-work visas (from the government's perspective) is to protect the job market, such that the work is held available for UK citizens (or others with that right, eg EU citizens for now and others to whom work visas have been issued). By performing such work, she would be depriving another of that opportunity—hence a violation of her non-work visa—irrespective of whether it's through a foreign company, or the means of payment.

Thank you Denis, that make sense. One follow up question though - do stock options, by definition, come with a grant price (term I picked up here http://personal.fidelity.com/products/stockoptions/exercise.shtml)? As in is it legal (or does it even make sense?) to offer "stock options to value of x% of capital" without defining grant price? From what I gathered: no, as I'd basically have to purchase those stocks for whatever they are at the time and then wait for their value to raise so I can make any money when selling them. Correct?

"stock _options_ to value of x% of capital" have a grant price by definition, because it's an option. An option is a promise to buy or sell at a given price at some point in the future. A stock _grant_, on the other hand, is a different story and has no such predetermined price - it's typically free or pre-purchased at any agreed upon price then and there. You'd usually see those creep in for high level execs as a bonus or VC types of investors who want to protect their interests in case of future dilutions.

That seems like a bit of a light overhead. Don't forget that your overhead should include your payroll as well as any other employees you may have. It also covers utilities, rent and any other tangible investments. Finally remember that your capacity is limited. If you're standard work week is 40 hrs. you'll have additional tasks to complete as the business owner. That means you can't count on having 40 billable hours a week for yourself. 70% or 28 hrs. may be all you can handle with other business tasks and acquiring clients so it's necessary to price your hourly rate appropriately.

Yes, I kept the overhead as low as possible. Currently looking to hire sales consultant. But I see your point. Thank you for the advice. Do you think that paying sales consultants on commission is better, or fix salary?

I tend to lean more on a hybrid approach where you apply a base salary amount and then let commissions cover the rest of the salary. This approach doesn't scare people as much because there is some stability with a great potential for growth. It also doesn't create an overzealous sales force whose only goal is to push sales and therefore commissions which many times will lead to over aggression and the possibility that you will run that customer off.

To elaborate a bit more, if you think it's reasonable based on a given sales area that a 100% commission salesperson should be able to earn $60,000/yr then you could provide a base salary of $20,000 or 33% and leave the other 67% or the salesperson's salary up to the commissions they make from sales. This provides a level of stability and a strong potential for salary growth beyond the estimated $60,000/yr which will instill confidence in your salespeople and make them more receptive to the back and forth courting nature necessary to acquire new clients.

I think you're misunderstanding. A stock option is an option (but not an obligation) to buy shares of stock. It looks like they will give you the option (but not the obligation) to buy enough shares to give you an 0.15% ownership of the company. The value cap sounds like it is the maximum amount of the company you can buy. So in other words, they will give you the option to buy 0.15% of the company, or up to $15K worth of the company, whichever is less.

Here's the part I think you're missing. When a company raises money from investors, the transaction implies a certain valuation for the company. For example, if an investor buys 50% of a company for $500K, that implies a valuation of $1 million for the entire company (if 50% sold for $500k, then 100% should sell for $1 million). It sounds like your company will be looking for investors and based on how much the get for some percentage, they will have a valuation. THEN and ONLY THEN can they determine how much 0.15% is and if it's less than a $15K cap. Does that make sense?
@Tom Dworzanski But shouldn't stock options ideally state the value/per share at which the employee can buy the equity?

Yes, there will be a stated amount you have to pay for a certain amount of stock (this is called a "strike price"). But they are not offering you a certain amount of stock, yet. They are telling you they will offer you some amount that will be equivalent to 0.15% based on some to-be-determined valuation. Neither you nor they know until they complete their investment round how much the valuation is and how much the 0.15% will cost.

Let's assume in a month they raise some money and it implies the company is worth $5,000,000. Once that happens, they will be able to offer you 0.15% of the company for $7,500 ($5,000,000 x 0.15% = $7,500). Since it's less than the $15,000 cap, you will be able to buy the full amount for $7,500 if you so choose. . . . Now, let's assume instead that the company is worth $20,000,000. In theory, they would offer you 0.15% of the company for $30,000. However, since this is over the cap, you would only be able to buy $15K. I'm not sure if you would get 0.15% or 0.075% in that case. You should ask.

Here's what I would do if I were in your position. 1) do done research on this guy and look at his other investments and companies that he's been involved in. How long has he been investing in start ups? What other proven and verified experience does he have? Go into our call and research his companies and see what the morale is like or similar. What's he involved in with the community? 2) if he doesn't have sufficient experience in business and startups, or you don't think you might get along with him because of

Other conflicting characteristics, then I would personally rather take a much lower percentage of the business (which has a current value if nothing yet, regardless of how optimistic everyone is), and take a higher hourly/project rate. I'd also state that as an incentive for you, after each milestone that you reach, say for example, sell 500 units of widgets, you're partner would give you an additional 10% of equity, then the business sells another 500 units (total of 1,000 for company) and you'd receive another 10%, until you reach 40%. This way, you get paid for

Your work, but also get equity in the business fire attaining milestones. He shouldn't have any problem with this. It's now more fair. Also if you decide he's not a good partner, you walk away with at least some cash for your work done and its a learning experience. 3) get this in writing...NO verbal agreements and preferably in writing with a witness or rotary. 4) IF you have a product that had potential liability, verify he had secured sufficient insurance, also make sure he establishes an LLC or similar (I'm not sure where you reside), make sure you're protected. Not sure why you say you're breaking GPL? The way I understand GPL (CHECK WITH AN ATTORNEY!), you have the right to license your work under other licenses (including closed-source) as well IF YOU ARE THE SOLE COPYRIGHT HOLDER (or get all copyright holders to agree to it). Thus, you can have the 'enterprise/commercial' license, and the 'community/open-source' license running simultaneously without 'breaking the GPL.' I know of multiple software companies that use this technique to increase market penetration while holding some features/etc back for pay under a multi-license-options scheme.

FWIW the key for dating apps isn't "reaching" X profiles in the system. You'll necessarily need to _buy_ dating profiles (which you can, just about all over the place) to bootstrap it to begin with, because no one signs up on an empty site. What actually counts is having a threshold of active females (active males are plenty) who aren't chat bots and actually accept dates. It's an extremely tough market, and if your performance incentive revolves around getting target number of profiles, you're probably setting yourself up for failure. If the two succeed at launching this be _very_ generous.

@Shub in that case, I'd say yes, file a provisional patent so you've got a stake in the ground. Among other things, that means you can mark your product as "patent pending" and sell it with patent law protection - but *any* patent application has to be done before you "publicly disclose [the] invention (e.g., publishes, uses, sells, or otherwise makes available to the public)" (quoting the USPTO page I cited). Just make sure you file the full application within 1 year of getting the provisional one, or you will lose all of the patent protection.

@Shub: I appreciate that you accepted this answer, but, for the sake of completeness, I would stress that FKEinternet also has a point. Namely, that filing can only be done up to a certain point. Basically, once it's public it's no longer patentable in practice. Now, in my experience (been there, done that, got involved in a couple of startups, some with patents some without) it doesn't matter _at all_ because at the end of the day product-market fit is all that matters unless you're a patent troll. But for future readers who read this thread, they should also be aware about it.

@shub My projection to you question on Stack Patents reflects a worst-case scenario. You definitely need an attorney for a non-provisional, but it's possible you could keep the cost in the $5,000 to $10,000 range if the invention is not in a "grey area" for eligibility and the mechanism is simple. (This would be with a solo practitioner, as opposed to a firm.) DO NOT use a mill such as LegalZoom, as they are likely to do more harm than good.

@shub a self-filed provisional is the cheap way to go for protecting the idea while trying to drum up investment. But you need to be careful in doing your research on what needs to be included (you need to describe the invention as clearly and comprehensively as possible.) If it's a consumer product, no one will invest before there is a proven market, but if it's something like a novel industrial process, or improvement to an existing process, with clear benefits, you may be able to attract money.

I strongly agree with FK regarding using a provisional to "stake your ground". If you never publicly disclose and make everybody you show it to sign non-disclosures, you can even refile a provisional after the initial provisional has expired. (Don't expect VC's to sign non-disclosures though, because it creates potential liability for them with no guaranteed benefit.)

As @DukeZhou has said, *if* you neither never publicly disclose your invention nor discuss it without an NDA during the initial provisional patent period, you *can* re-file. However, you will lose the filing date of the original application as the date of the patent if it's granted - the date of the re-file would be the effective date of the patent if one were issued.

I would ***SERIOUSLY*** recommend against *not* getting a patent if you think your idea *could* benefit from patent protection: As soon as you sell or otherwise publicly disclose your idea, you lose the opportunity to **ever** get a patent. The price of a provisional patent could easily be trivial compared to the financial advantage of *having* a patent - and having a provisional patent allows you to sell, etc. to otherwise determine the market for your product ***without*** losing the ability to patent it.

I doubt that a court would rule in favor of a trademark registered _ex post facto_. If the trademark existed, and _then_ the other entity created a handle that infringed, it's possible, but not guaranteed, that the trademark holder could prevail. Though he reached a settlement, it's not certain which way [Microsoft v. MikeRoweSoft](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microsoft_vs._MikeRoweSoft) would have ended.

The idea has no cash value until someone offers to buy it. Bankers can't meet their obligations without cashable collateral. If you are paying your salary from accumulated debt, you're starting in a position where one emergency can bring everything down.

@Calaf -- when you start a company and contribute cash or other valuable assets, those contributions are either debt or equity: either a loan or an outright contribution. They have different tax consequences. Payments on a loan are made up of taxable interest and non-taxable repayment of principal (the amount of the original loan). If it's not a loan and the company makes the same payments to its shareholders the entire amount is taxable as a dividend. That's why the IRS cares, and if they determine that the "debt" was intended to avoid taxes, they can recharacterize it as equity.

@Calaf -- just a clarification to my previous comment: when I said "taxable interest" I meant taxable **to the recipient**; similarly for "taxable as a dividend". Further, interest payments are deductible for the company but dividends are not.
